text:
Hi everyone :) I’m a physics student in Mexico and I’m interested in participating in GSoC 2021, this is my first time participating. I’m particularly interested in the NOVAS project, is anyone already working on it?

I saw in the description of the project that the project is of medium difficulty. I consider myself a beginner in the Julia language, however, I consider I could dedicate a fair amount of time to study the language in April since I’m only writing my thesis at the moment, would you consider that’s enough time to make a good work for GSoC?

I see that there exists a package that’s called einsteinpy regarding general relativity. Since that’s a topic I like, I was wondering if there would be someone interested in being a mentor of a project related to it? I can think of maybe making a Julia version of a ray tracer, like the one proposed in this paper:
<http://courses.csail.mit.edu/18.337/2015/projects/RyanMcKinnon/report.pdf>

text:
The easiest way to 1) know more Julia and 2) help your GSoC is to contribute doctests/docstrings to your package of interest.
This is a great article for starting out with the git workflow expected during the GSoC.
<https://kshyatt.github.io/post/firstjuliapr/>

attachments.title: Making a first Julia pull request | Katharine Hyatt
attachments.text: In this post I'm going to go through my step-by-step process of finding some code in base Julia which is not covered by tests, adding tests which do cover it, checking to make sure the tests pass, and finally opening a pull request to have my changes merged in to Julia itself. We'll be working off commit 0b0a394b3e7741d38f00dbb29895b6ba6a7d0767 if you want to follow along. (To do so, you can git checkout 0b0a394b3e7741d38f00dbb29895b6ba6a7d0767.

text: hi again Magdalena! regarding the other project you're thinking about, you can ask in <#C78UK7F1Q|physics>, it's great you have your own ideas :blush:  regarding the NOVAS project, you can ask Paul for more details about the scientific case, but at the moment you're mainly expected to do a couple of PRs (maybe to other JuliaAstro projects) to show familiarity with julia and the git/github workflow.  the resource linked above by Miguel is good!
